head.title: Middlesex School District School District in Middlesex, VT. | GreatSchools

meta.name: description
meta.content: Information to help parents choose the right public school for their children in the Middlesex School District.

GreatSchools’ Summary Rating provides an overall snapshot of school quality. Ratings follow a 1-10 scale, where top-rated schools are "10s":

  • ratings between 1-4 signal “below average”
  • 5-6 indicate “average”
  • ratings of 7-10 are “above average”

GreatSchools’ Summary Rating provides an overall snapshot of school quality.
For some schools, we do not have enough data from state or national education agencies to provide a rating.

finances","finance.module_subtitle":"How a school district allocates funds can reflect its priorities. Learn more about how these decisions are made.","finance.parent_tip":"District decisions about how to spend money impact your child’s schooling. Here’s how parents can have an influence.","finance.RevenueSources":"Revenue sources","finance.ExpenditureSources":"Spending by category","finance.RevenueSources_tooltip_html":"This is a breakdown of how much of this district’s total annual funds came from federal, state, or local sources, compared to state averages:

Federal: Funds from the federal government, which can include money for Title 1 schools, vocational and tech education, bilingual education, and the Child Nutrition Act, and more.

State: Funds from the state government, which can include money for staff improvement, special education, gifted and talented, bilingual, and vocational education, school lunch, transportation, and employee benefits, and more.

Local: Funds from local sources, which can include money from parent organizations like a PTA/PTO; local property, sales, or utility taxes, and transportation, and more. ","finance.ExpenditureSources_tooltip_html":"This is a breakdown of annual district spending on preK-12 education and other categories:

Instruction: Spending on preK-12 instruction, including teacher salaries and materials for regular, special, and vocational programs during the school year and summer, and more.

Support services: Spending on administrative support for preK-12 education, including professional development, counselors, transportation, materials, and more.

Other preK-12 spending: Spending on preK-12 spending outside of instruction and support services.

Other spending: Other spending, including community services, adult education, and spending on things like buildings and roads. ","finance.data_types.Total Revenue":"Total district revenue","finance.data_types.Per Pupil Revenue":"Average revenue per student","finance.data_types.Percent Federal Revenue":"Federal","finance.data_types.Percent State Revenue":"State","finance.data_types.Percent Local Revenue":"Local","finance.data_types.Total Expenditures":"Total district spending","finance.data_types.Per Pupil Expenditures":"Average spending per student","finance.data_types.Percent Instructional Expenditures":"Instruction","finance.data_types.Percent Support Services Expenditures":"Support services","finance.data_types.Percent Other Expenditures":"Other preK-12 spending","finance.data_types.Percent Uncategorized Expenditures":"Other spending","finance.tool_tips.Total Revenue":"This reflects the total annual funds this district received from local, state, and federal sources, compared to the average across the state. (See examples below).","finance.tool_tips.Per Pupil Revenue":"This reflects how much annual revenue per student this district has compared to the state average. The revenue per student figure offers a helpful way to compare districts, since total revenues will vary greatly between large and small districts.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Federal Revenue":"This shows the share of this district’s revenues received from the federal government, which can include funds for Title 1 schools and programs like Safe and Drug Free Schools, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, vocational and tech education, bilingual education, and the Child Nutrition Act, among others.","finance.tool_tips.Percent State Revenue":"This shows the share of this district’s revenues received from the state government, which can include funds for programs including staff improvement, special education, gifted and talented education, bilingual education, vocational education, school lunch, transportation, employee benefits, and facilities, among others.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Local Revenue":"This reflects the share of this district’s revenues that came from local sources, which can include contributions from parent organizations like a PTA/PTO; local property, sales, or utility taxes, fees paid by students for textbooks, transportation, and school lunch, and revenues from rent or property sales, among others.","finance.tool_tips.Total Expenditures":"This is a breakdown of this district’s total spending, including spending on preK-12 education, adult education, payments to governments, private or charter schools, spending on buildings, roads, and equipment, and more.","finance.tool_tips.Per Pupil Expenditures":"This reflects how much money this district spent on a per-student basis, compared to the state average. This figure can help you compare districts to one another.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Instructional Expenditures":"This reflects the percentage of this district’s annual spending on teacher salaries, benefits, supplies, materials and other costs associated with preK-12 instruction, including regular, special, and vocational, programs during the school year and summer school.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Support Services Expenditures":"This reflects the percentage of this district’s annual spending on administrative, technical, and logistical supports for preK -12 education, including professional development, counselors, supplies, transportation, materials, and more.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Other Expenditures":"This reflects the percentage of this district’s annual spending on other preK-12 expenditures outside of instruction and support services.","finance.tool_tips.Percent Uncategorized Expenditures":"This reflects the percentage this district’s annual spending on programs not part of preK-12 spending, including community services, adult education, and on capital expenditures like buildings, roads, and other improvements.","academic_progress.toc_item":"Academic progress","student_progress.toc_item":"Student progress","top_schools.state_top_schools_header":"Best public schools in {state}","top_schools.top_schools":"Top schools","top_schools.top_schools_blurbs":"These are some of the top-rated public schools in {name} based on a variety of measures, including academic performance and equity. Click to see the full list of schools sorted by rating. About the GreatSchools rating ","top_schools.top_schools_test_score_ratings_blurb":"These are some of the top-rated public schools in {name} based on their Test Score Rating. Click to see the full list of schools sorted by rating.About the GreatSchools rating ","top_schools.csa_top_schools_blurb":"These are some of the best public high schools in {name} at preparing students for success in college. The College Success Award recognizes schools that do an exemplary job getting students to enroll in and stick with college, including those that beat the odds by better serving low-income students. ","top_schools.learn_more":"Learn more","top_schools.see_elem":"See more elementary schools","top_schools.see_mid":"See more middle schools","top_schools.see_high":"See more high schools"};gon.data_layer_hash={"language":"en","page_name":"GS:District:Home","City":"Middlesex","State":"VT","county":"Washington","env":"prod","gs_badge":"CSAnullstate"};gon.facebook_app_id="112862918759431";gon.homes_and_rentals_service_url="https://www.greatschools.org/homes-and-rentals-service";gon.dependencies={"highcharts":"/assets/highcharts-995d8719f75b4db7a9a841f2715b6045.js"}; //

div.script:
{"title":"Academics","anchor":"Academics","subtitle":"Is this district offering opportunity for all its students, or leaving some kids behind? Successful districts are working to close the achievement gap. ","info_text":null,"icon_classes":"icon-pie","sources":"

GreatSchools district data sources & information

Smarter Balanced Assessment

Reading, Math

The new assessment replaces Vermont's previous tests in English language arts and mathematics, known as the NECAP (New England Common Assessment Program). The Smarter Balanced test asks students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge and skills in areas such as critical thinking, analytical writing, and problem solving.

Source: Vermont Agency of Education, 2015

Big differences may suggest that some student groups are not getting the support they need to succeed. ","type":"bar","values":{"Smarter Balanced Assessment":[{"breakdown":"All students","label":"75","score":75,"state_average":53,"state_average_label":"53","percentage":null,"number_students_tested":92,"grade":"All","display_percentages":true,"subject":"Reading","test_description":"The new assessment replaces Vermont's previous tests in English language arts and mathematics, known as the NECAP (New England Common Assessment Program). The Smarter Balanced test asks students to demonstrate and apply their knowledge and skills in areas such as critical thinking, analytical writing, and problem solving.","test_label":"Smarter Balanced Assessment","test_source":"Vermont Agency of Education","year":"2015","state_number_tested":23768,"grades":[{"label":"68","score":68,"state_average":51,"state_average_label":"51","percentage":null,"number_students_tested":16,"grade":"3","display_percentages":true},{"label":"70","score":70,"state_average":50,"state_average_label":"50","percentage":null,"number_students_tested":34,"grade":"4","display_percentages":true},{"label":"85","score":85,"state_average":56,"state_average_label":"56","percentage":null,"number_students_tested":21,"grade":"5","display_percentages":true},{"label":"80","score":80,"state_average":53,"state_average_label":"53","percentage":null,"number_students_tested":21,"grade":"6","display_percentages":true}]}]},"flagged":null,"title":"Reading","anchor":"Reading"}]}],"analytics_id":"Academics","showTabs":null,"faq":{"cta":"Notice something missing or confusing?","content":"

Missing a race or ethnicity? When the population of a student group is too small to provide reliable data, it does not show up in the display. This may cause certain races/ethnicities not appearing in some charts within this section.

How do we come up with the race/ethnicity labels? We display the language used by the State Department of Education to describe student races and ethnicities.

  • The “All students” number displayed represents the number of students who participated in testing.
  • The “% of students” information reflects the portion of the overall student population that each subgroup represents. For more about student demographics, visit the “Students” section below.

How do we decide which subjects to display? Test subjects shown represent those taken by the largest number of students.

Still have questions? Visit our FAQ page.

div.h2: Community resources in Middlesex School District

div.span: Learn more about this district's school board and how you can get involved.

a.data-content-html:
GreatSchools district data sources & information

School Board Finder

Source: XQ

div.p: GreatSchools is the leading national nonprofit empowering parents to unlock educational opportunities for their children. We provide school information and parenting resources to help millions of American families choose the right school, support learning at home, and guide their children to great futures.

br.p: Support GreatSchools in this effort! Donate Now!
